comment._content: I'm not 100% sure, but I suspect that the dapper chap in the suit is ?Charles/Clarence Hipwell (still not certain re his given name), who was superintendent of steelworks erection for the Harbour Bridge contractor, Dorman Long & Co. I gather this pic was taken at one of the top chord centre joints on 10/9/1930, the day the top chord was joined (the lower chord having been temporarily joined a few weeks previously). Over at SRNSW they have a number of pics dated 10/9/1930 which were taken at this same location...including this one investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/search.as... ...judging by the position of the steel 'packs' which we see here in the foreground, it appears that this PHM collection pic was taken on the same day. Over at NSW Transport RMS they have the same SRNSW pic (albeit in reverse) with an accompanying caption, which identifies Hipwell...trove.nla.gov.au/work/168965247?q=nuc%3ANRTA+sydney+harbo... ...like the chap in this PHM collection pic, Hipwell is wearing what appears to be a white cardigan underneath his suit jacket. My only reservation with the caption is that it appears to have mistaken Ralph Freeman for Frank Litchfield...which might perhaps raise questions re the accuracy of the caption as a whole. Freeman's SMH article on the closure of the top chord (link below) suggests he wasn't at the top chord on 10/9/1930. Hipwell is also identified in this other NSW Transport RMS pic trove.nla.gov.au/work/168706425?q=bradfield;+ennis;+litch... ...the PHM version provides a better view (zoom in on the PURL version) www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8283744212/in/pho... I gather Hipwell also appears in this PHM collection pic www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8282715717/ ...and he can also probably be tentatively identified in a number of other Harbour Bridge pics from the various collections. This 1932 SMH feature article includes a pic of the Dorman Long & Co Harbour Bridge staff nla.gov.au/nla.news-page1157143 ...the resolution isn't great...here we see Hipwell in the front row lhs... For interest, here's Ralph Freeman's fascinating article on the closure of the top chord which appeared in the SMH the following day - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16670396 ; this equally fascinating video (which includes commentary by former NSW Public Works Department engineer Frank Litchfield) more or less describes what's going on in this pic...it covers the joining of the lower and upper chords from ca. 12:00 thru to ca. 19:50 - www.youtube.com/watch?v=JPQ7CzVHdMs Here are some of the other SRNSW collection pics dated 10/9/1930 taken at one of the top chord centre joints...here we see l-r: Lawrence Ennis and JJC Bradfield - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/search.as... ; here we see l-r: Gordon Stuckey, RJ Butler, Frank Litchfield (supervising engineers with the NSW PWD) - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/search.as... I wonder whether it might be possible to identify some of the chaps in overalls...the blokes who actually built the bridge. They all appear to be wearing everyday shoes with leather soles. Not a harness, safety line or hard hat in sight.
